content:
I'm surprised moving and sorting don't work for you. They do for me. See the attached animated GIF (hope this works!)

You are right - drag-and-dropping folders is a delicate operation, but if your aim isn't true the first time, you can always move it again. But "Reset Folder Order" is less error-prone.

I've never seen that different folder icon and I don't know what it means. Right-click on it and examine the Properties - is there anything obviously different than the other folders? (See attached image.) If there's something about it that makes it non-movable, maybe you could make a new folder, move the messages there, then delete the old folder - perhaps they will be sortable then.
creator: rednoise

content: Your 2024 folder has an "Archives" icon and Archives is a system folder contrary to the other "year folders" which are generic. There is no risk to move it in one of the yellow generic folders because it won't work. But why does the 2024 folder have a system folder icon? Go to Account Settings > account name > Copies & Folders > Message Archives and verify if folder 2024 has been chosen as destination folder for archived messages .... If necessary to go even further you may install the FolderFlags add-on https://services.addons.thunderbird.net/En-uS/thunderbird/addon/folderflags/ , then R-click on 2024 > Properties > Flags .... and remove a possible "Archives" flag. Perhaps this will change the system folder in a generic folder?
creator: Mapenzi

content: Bingo! Installing the folder flags add-on showed me (as you said) that 2024 was flagged as an archive. I turned the flag off, restarted TBird and 2024 now comes after 2023 as it should. I expect I created the problem somehow when I moved the 2024 folder from the server to Local Folders; what is the proper way to do that?
creator: ronks1

content: First, I saw your question and it made me curious. I have no idea why that is happening, but I am sure it is being done by Gmail, not Thunderbird. I suggest checking Gmail online to see if it is placing those messages elsewhere, such as the Important folder. And, just a reminder, the email will always be in Allmail.The question is to find why it is not also in the inbox, but elsewhere. My hope is that you will find the message online in a different folder and that may help you in resolving this. Good luck.

content:
frank-solingen said
Hello, I have been having problems authenticating my AOL email account for two weeks. Nothing I try works. Every time I open the AOL authentication window, I get the message "Something went wrong. I have created an app password for Thunderbird several times in my AOL account. I named this app password Thunderbird. The account is an SMTP IMAP account and the ports are correct. I have now completely deleted my AOL email account in Thunderbird and also deleted the AOL passwords. The authentication method for outh2 is selected and cookies are enabled. I can do whatever I want, but the authentication still doesn't work. What else could be the problem? I'm at a loss now. Frank

When the OAuth2 window appears, enter the account (not app) password. Check that cookies are accepted in TB (not browser) Settings/Privacy & Security. Disable a VPN if one is enabled.

Settings: imap.aol.com, 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address; smtp.aol.com, 465, SSL/TLS, OAuth2, email address.

content:
Hello there


There is not really a lot of information about : Inbox shows huge number of emails but I can't see them. Thank you in advance.

These kind of issues are and can be the fault of broken msf.files or outdated or broken add ons or extensions during the use of the Thunderbird program.

Try to walk along with these fixes to find out if this issue is really that and good to solve. What other email-programs are there? Can i ask?


1. Security software on that pc can be restarted or reseted to find out more if it was blocking something there after just recent updates .

2. Go for the repair folder option in thunderbird. Go and click right on that inbox with issues and choose and go for the repair folder option. -right click on the inbox menu -choose properties -general information tab , click the repair folder buttons. -click on oke.

3. if the repair folder did not work that well there , then you can consider to use the option to delete the msf.files from the thunderbird map that is stored in and configured in the profile map ,going there deleting all these inbox msf.files and look carefully for more because there are more then one msf.files of them it rebuilds all of them by deleting them and restarting thunderbird and after to see if the inbox issue has finished now.

4. Other option are to use the trouble shoot mode for the search of outdated or broken add ons and to delete or update them if found : https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird

5, There are filters that can be used that only show 'unread' messages, making the rest seem invisible on the software program : Press Ctrl >shift >K to delete certain filters in the quick filter bar.for windows. For mac os cmd>shift>k. Or choose for the option View>threads>set to all , high lighted and chosen it tells the email client to select all and view all .


Turn off the view settings and installed filters in thunderbird for a moment to see. Using other email programs in the client can have more options to solve this issue.
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content: If you want to synchronise folders and messages of an email account on several devices you should use the IMAP protocol on account set up.
creator: Mapenzi

content: Thank you, can you please provide more details (workflow) to make this adjustment?
creator: camp32

content: If you are not familiar with the differences between email accounts set up using the POP or the IMAP protocol please consult this help article https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/difference-between-imap-and-pop3 IMAP servers keep folders and messages on the server. An IMAP account set up in an email client on a desktop computer will automatically be synchronised with the same email address set up as IMAP account in another email client on another device, desktop or mobile. We need more details about your Thunderbird installations on desktop and on your mobile device to give further advice about how to gain synchronisation between them
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Try this:

  1. create an empty folder in drive D. any name will do. I suggest NOT having any spaces in name
  2. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  3. scroll to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles'
  4. click the button to create new profile
  5. enter a short name, such as DRIVED
  6. click Next
  7. click 'choose' and select the folder on drive D that you created
  8. click finish
  9. , now, the active profile is in the listed profiles on the screen. click 'open folder'
  10. exit thunderbird - IMPORTANT
  11. you are in the profile for the current profile. select ALL and COPY to clipboard
  12. click to the new empty folder on drive D and PASTE contents there
  13. now, restart thunderbird. you are still in old profile at the moment
  14. click help>troubleshootinginformation and, again, scroll to 'profiles' and click 'about:profiles'
  15. your new profile is listed. set it as default
  16. all should now be okay. thunderbird may want to restart.
  17. when al is well and done, you can then delete the profile from drive C.
  18. I think you've earned a beer and some peanuts to celebrate.

NOTE; in future, if you install thunderbird to a new PC, you will save time by backing the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder NOW. Then, on the reinstall, do it in these steps: - install thunderbird on new pc and start once and exit - replace the existing appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder with the backup - when you now restart thunderbird, it will be using the profile on drive D
creator: davidsk

content: Go to Help > Troubleshooting information > Profile Folder > Open Folder, then close Thunderbird. In the profile folder search for the global-messages-db.sqlite file and delete it. On Thunderbird restart the search index file will be recreated; this might take some minutes up to several hours, depending on how many folders and messages are stored in your profile. You can follow the indexing progress by opening the Activity Manager window via the Tools menu.
creator: Mapenzi

content: The file is explicitly abook.sqlite. The others are built on it. If the folders are still there, please look again. I regret you're having this difficulty.

content:
A couple of things to check:

- Are the fonts settings the same in both? (Edit | Settings | General | Language & Fonts)?

- Are they both using the same Theme (Tools | Add-Ons and Themes | Themes)?

- Try disabling or enabling Hardware Acceleration in the errant computer (Edit | Settings | General | Use hardware acceleration when available).

My two Mint computers, one Mint 22, the other Mint 22.3, both using Thunderbird 140.7.1esr, both say "Thunderbird for Linux Mint -mint-001 - 1.0" like yours. Don't know the significance of that.

content: No, you are wrong! On https://www.thunderbird.net/ the Thunderbird installer file ist first downloaded, and only when the download is finished the page automatically changes to a donation page. Probably you don't notice that the installer file has already been saved somewhere in your download folder. Same problem as in https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1563196
